newsitem.title: MOROCCO: Moroccan minister says no plan to devalue dirham.
newsitem.headline: Moroccan minister says no plan to devalue dirham.

text.p: Moroccan Finance Minister Mohamed Kabbaj said on Thursday Rabat had no plan to devalue its local currency, the dirham, despite persistent rumours on the market.
The dirham has fluctuated in recent weeks at between 8.5 and 8.7 dirhams against the U.S. dollar.
"These are normal flucutations...In any case we have no plans to devalue our national currency," the minister told Reuters.
France is Morocco's leading European Union trading partner and some exporters, fearing increased competition from their Spanish counterparts, have argued in favour of devaluation.
Against the French franc, the dirham has been trading recently at between 1.6 and 1.7 dirhams.
The dirham is at present not fully convertible except for transactions by foreign companies operating in Morocco and for local firms engaged in business abroad.
A Bank al-Maghrib (central bank) official said earlier: "It (devaluation) would have a negative impact on the economy."
The Moroccan dirham was last devalued officially by 9.25 perecent in 1990.
